content: Great question, and pretty funny that at the time of writing all(!) 27 responses say 'no', and I can only agree.
There's no such thing as schemaless, in Mongo however the schema is implied and not strictly enforced.
Mongo is definitely not common in the corporate world and I've never encountered someone with a real job praising it.
In other words, whatever shape the data is you put in your mongo database is the schema
If people are using Javascript/Python to build big applications then why is mongo bad and Node.js not bad with that logic?
One thing I don't see mentioned here are CQRS systems. I'm using Mongo for the read side of my CQRS system.
Mongo is fine as a secondary data store or a prototype but SQL + Redis is still the best.
It's a gateway drug into the world of data storage and manipulation, but for production, SQL wins hands down every time
I wouldnt discount Mongos cloud offering but its just not something that comes to mind.
Postgres seems to be the most popular recently from my exp., but I've also worked with companies using Microsoft, Oracle, MySQL, cockroach, etc.
